newsitem.title: CANADA: Quebec village gets its own "monarch".
newsitem.headline: Quebec village gets its own "monarch".

text.p: This small Quebec community anointed one of its residents the first "mayor-king" in North America on Tuesday.

More than 5,000 people flocked to participate in ceremonies for the coronation of Denys the First as "king" on Quebec's main annual holiday in this village of 1,300 people 186 miles (300 km) north of Quebec City.
The event coincided with a visit to Canada by its head of state, Queen Elizabeth, who was in Newfoundland on Tuesday.

The spoof coronation was the brainchild of mayor Denys Tremblay, a 46-year-old artist and tourism promoter. In January, residents voted 73 percent in favour of turning the village into a mock monarchy and making him "king".
A year after flash floods destroyed the village, the coronation was a tongue-in-cheek opportunity for local people to celebrate a symbolic rebirth.

Tremblay said he hoped to attract tourists to L'Anse Saint-Jean. He also wants to raise C$1 million ($720,000) to landscape a nearby hillside, using trees and shrubs to fashion the likeness of St. John the Baptist, the Roman Catholic saint honoured on Quebec's holiday.

His first two achievements were more modest. A local brewery created a commemorative beer named "La Royale", and he secured C$18,000 ($12,900) from the Canadian government's arts council for his crown and jewels.
